Derek James wrote:

>Hi Colin,
>
>Are you sure this network as learned XOR, and not the
>particular sequence of inputs?
>
>Is the network memory flushed out before the next
>input is fed into it?  Have you tried shuffling the
>order of the input and gotten the same responses?
>
>Ken's right...technically you should disable
>recurrency when attempting to solve XOR.  But if this
>network isn't memorizing the sequence, then I'd agree
>that it is interesting. :)
>
>  
>
Hi Derek, Ken,

I had considered that networks may learn the testing sequence so yes I 
do reset each neuron's output for each test, and therefore there is no 
need to shuffle the test sequences. Besides which the truth table I 
posted was calculated manually to confirm the result! - it is only small 
after all. Looking at the truth table it does make sense: 

0    1    2    3(t0)    3(t1)
--------------------------
1    0    0    0.83     0.01
1    0    1    0.16     0.05
1    1    0    0.16     0.05
1    1    1    0.007    0.007


The large negative weight on the output node (-7.4) has the effect of 
reducing larger signals from the previous time step more than small 
ones. So 0.83 becomes 0.01, whereas 0.016 becomes 0.05. The point is 
that the larger signal became the smaller and visa versa. This large 
negative loopback weight would also have the effect of reducing all 
output to 0.0 if I relaxed the network based upon waiting for a stable 
ouput value (I read the FAQ entry thanks Ken).

Ken, yes t0 and t1 are the output of node 3 at times steps 0 and 1. 
Really that should be t1 and t2, since all outputs are 0 at t0.

One more interesting point, the maximum seperation between true and 
false always came out the same for all the runs I performed... 0.045. 
(Note that the numbers in the table are rounded).


Colin.
